module.title: proper nouns
module.p: Proper nouns are nouns which are also names, identifying and referring to a single entity – a specific person, place, organisation &c.
Like all nouns, proper nouns have a gender – they are either feminine or masculine –

ul.li: Mairead Margaret and Sasainn England are examples of feminine proper nouns.
Seumas James and Bòd Bute are example of masculine proper nouns.

module.p: Since they refer to single entities, all proper nouns are singular. There are no plural proper nouns.
Like all nouns, proper nouns are declined for case – they can have nominative, dative and genitive forms –

ul.li: The dative and genitive forms of Mairead are both Maireid.
The genitive forms of Seumas and Bòd are Sheumais and Bhòid respectively.

module.p: Like other nouns, proper nouns can be modified by attributive adjectives, e.g. Seumas Beag Little James, Mairead bhàn bhòidheach pretty fair Margaret, Sasainn Nuadh New England. Capitalisation of the adjective depends on whether it is assumed to be part of the (nick)name of the entity.
Like other names, proper nouns belong to different semantic classes, depending on the kind of entity they identify –

ol.li: Anthroponymic proper nouns name people (including personified entities) eg. Mairead, Seumas.
Toponymic proper nouns name places (geographical entities) eg. Bòd, Sasainn.
‘Grouponymic’ proper nouns name groups, teams, organisations, companies &c eg. Misneachd [name of pressure group], CNAG [name of government agency].
‘Textonymic’ proper nouns name scholarly and literary texts and other creative works eg. Gairm [name of quarterly periodical], Bannan [name of television drama serial].
Glottonymic proper nouns name languages and dialects eg. Laideann Latin.

module.p: Note that ‘grouponymic’ and ‘textonymic’ proper nouns are often derived from common nouns eg. Misneachd (from misneachd confidence), Gairm (from gairm calling). For convenience, these can be termed improper nouns. Other proper nouns are acronyms eg. CNAG (from Comunn na Gàidhlig).
